input:
2. A 5-year-old male was referred to a developmental pediatrician due to delayed milestones and limited expressive language. His parents reported that he rarely made eye contact and exhibited repetitive hand-flapping behaviors. Neurological examination revealed generalized hypotonia and mild joint hypermobility. The child had difficulty with problem-solving tasks and showed poor social interaction compared to peers. There was no history of seizures, but he experienced frequent ear infections during infancy. Brain MRI was unremarkable, and metabolic screening was normal. Family history was notable for intellectual disability in the mother’s brother, suggesting an X-linked pattern. Genetic analysis confirmed a mutation in the gene associated with Mental Retardation, X-Linked 97.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: The parent seems worried but maybe also unsure what exactly is going on. They might be feeling overwhelmed or confused about their child's condition and what to expect. I should keep my response simple and show understanding without overwhelming them with medical jargon.

ANSWER: I'm his mom, and I guess I'm just really worried because he's not like other kids his age. He doesn't talk much or look at us, and sometimes he does things over and over, and I don't know if that's normal or not.

input: 2. A 5-year-old male was referred to a developmental pediatrician due to delayed milestones and limited expressive language. His parents reported that he rarely made eye contact and exhibited repetitive hand-flapping behaviors. Neurological examination revealed generalized hypotonia and mild joint hypermobility. The child had difficulty with problem-solving tasks and showed poor social interaction compared to peers. There was no history of seizures, but he experienced frequent ear infections during infancy. Brain MRI was unremarkable, and metabolic screening was normal. Family history was notable for intellectual disability in the mother’s brother, suggesting an X-linked pattern. Genetic analysis confirmed a mutation in the gene associated with Mental Retardation, X-Linked 97.Can you tell me more about how your child interacts with other children and adults, and if there are any other behaviors or concerns you've noticed over time?
output: Um, he doesn’t really play or talk with other kids much, and he seems kind of shy or maybe confused sometimes. He mostly just does his own thing, like flapping his hands or staring, and I’ve noticed he doesn’t look at us much either. Sometimes he gets really upset or cranky for no clear reason, and I worry it’s more than just being little.

input: 2. A 5-year-old male was referred to a developmental pediatrician due to delayed milestones and limited expressive language. The child had difficulty with problem-solving tasks and showed poor social interaction compared to peers. There was no history of seizures, but he experienced frequent ear infections during infancy. Brain MRI was unremarkable, and metabolic screening was normal. Family history was notable for intellectual disability in the mother’s brother, suggesting an X-linked pattern. Genetic analysis confirmed a mutation in the gene associated with Mental Retardation, X-Linked 97.Can you tell me more about your child's daily routines, what activities he enjoys or dislikes, and if you've noticed any specific situations or times when he seems more upset or behaviorally different?
output: Well, he mostly likes just playing with his favorite toys, but sometimes he gets really upset when things change or if he's asked to do something he doesn’t want to do. He doesn’t seem to really enjoy sitting still for long, and he sometimes gets very upset in noisy places or when he's tired.

input: 2. A 5-year-old male was referred to a developmental pediatrician due to delayed milestones and limited expressive language. His parents reported that he rarely made eye contact and exhibited repetitive hand-flapping behaviors. Neurological examination revealed generalized hypotonia and mild joint hypermobility. The child had difficulty with problem-solving tasks and showed poor social interaction compared to peers. There was no history of seizures, but he experienced frequent ear infections during infancy. Brain MRI was unremarkable, and metabolic screening was normal. Family history was notable for intellectual disability in the mother’s brother, suggesting an X-linked pattern. Genetic analysis confirmed a mutation in the gene associated with Mental Retardation, X-Linked 97.Can you tell me more about how your child behaves during different times of the day, such as playtime, mealtime, or when he's with other children or family members?
output: Well, um, during playtime, he doesn't seem to really want to play with others much. He often just kind of flaps his hands and looks away. At mealtime, he sometimes doesn't eat much and seems distracted, like he's not really paying attention. When he's with other kids or family, he mostly keeps to himself and doesn't really talk or look at us much. Sometimes he gets pretty clingy or just sort of stares off.

input: 2. A 5-year-old male was referred to a developmental pediatrician due to delayed milestones and limited expressive language. His parents reported that he rarely made eye contact and exhibited repetitive hand-flapping behaviors. Neurological examination revealed generalized hypotonia and mild joint hypermobility. The child had difficulty with problem-solving tasks and showed poor social interaction compared to peers. There was no history of seizures, but he experienced frequent ear infections during infancy. Brain MRI was unremarkable, and metabolic screening was normal. Family history was notable for intellectual disability in the mother’s brother, suggesting an X-linked pattern. Genetic analysis confirmed a mutation in the gene associated with Mental Retardation, X-Linked 97.Can you tell me if your child has started using any words or gestures to communicate, such as pointing or waving, and if he responds appropriately when you call his name or ask him to do things?
output: Um, he doesn’t really say words or do much with his hands like waving, and sometimes I call him, but he doesn’t always look or respond like I expect. It’s kind of like he’s not really noticing me sometimes.

The child had difficulty with problem-solving tasks and showed poor social interaction compared to peers. There was no history of seizures, but he experienced frequent ear infections during infancy. Brain MRI was unremarkable, and metabolic screening was normal. Family history was notable for intellectual disability in the mother’s brother, suggesting an X-linked pattern. Genetic analysis confirmed a mutation in the gene associated with Mental Retardation, X-Linked 97.How does your child respond when you introduce him to new people or place him in unfamiliar environments?
output: He usually gets kinda quiet and just kind of stares or looks away. Sometimes, he flaps his hands or seems upset if he's in a new place. He's not really someone who makes a lot of eye contact with new people.

input: 2. A 5-year-old male was referred to a developmental pediatrician due to delayed milestones and limited expressive language. His parents reported that he rarely made eye contact and exhibited repetitive hand-flapping behaviors. Neurological examination revealed generalized hypotonia and mild joint hypermobility. The child had difficulty with problem-solving tasks and showed poor social interaction compared to peers. There was no history of seizures, but he experienced frequent ear infections during infancy. Brain MRI was unremarkable, and metabolic screening was normal. Family history was notable for intellectual disability in the mother’s brother, suggesting an X-linked pattern. Genetic analysis confirmed a mutation in the gene associated with Mental Retardation, X-Linked 97.Has your child shown any reactions to certain sounds, lights, textures, or crowds—such as covering his ears, avoiding certain textures, or becoming overwhelmed in noisy environments?
output: Um, sometimes he seems to get really upset or cover his ears when things are loud, but I don’t always know if that’s what’s bothering him or if he’s just upset about something else. He also doesn’t really like certain textures, like if his clothes are itchy, and he sometimes gets overwhelmed at noisy places. I’m not sure if that’s normal or if it’s more than that.
